The New York press reported on gold deposits carried to the United States on the liner several times on the Antwerp route. In a storm-tossed December 1920 voyage, for example, she carried $1,650,000 in gold, and the following June she carried £100,000 gold to the [[Equitable Trust Company of New York|Equitable Trust Company]] in New York.{{cite news | title = Gold movements | work = The Wall Street Journal | date = 27 June 1921 | page = 5 }} Another notable cargo arrived in New York in November 1922, when ''Kroonland'' brought {{convert|840000|lb|kg}} of cheese from [[Switzerland]]. The shipment was said to be the first big shipment from that country since before World War I.{{cite news | url = http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D0CE0DF1F3EEE3ABC4051DFB7678389639EDE | format = pdf | title = Kroonland brings huge cheese cargo | work = The New York Times | date = 28 November 1922 | accessdate = 21 June 2008 | page = 41 }} A more unwelcome cargo was carried in March 1921, when a Hungarian immigrant in steerage was found to have [[typhoid fever]]. Discovery of the disease necessitated that all 731 steerage passengers be quarantined indefinitely.{{cite news | url = http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C01EFDB133CE533A25754C0A9659C946095D6CF | format = pdf | title = Six more typhus cases in the city | work = The New York Times | date = 7 March 1921 | accessdate = 21 June 2008 | page = 1 }} ''Kroonland'' began her last voyage on the Antwerp route in January 1923, after which she underwent a refit during the first half of 1923. The ship was converted to cabin- and third-class passengers only, and was painted white.{{cite news | title = Service of fast liners for harbor | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 9 July 1923 | page = I–8 }} In preparation for her announced return to the Panama Pacific Line in October 1923, more refrigeration and cool air space were added for transporting Southern California agricultural products. After this refit, the ship was briefly assigned to the American Line for three roundtrips on a New York to [[Hamburg]] route, with intermediate stops at Plymouth and [[Cherbourg]]. On her first Hamburg trip, she carried American comedic actress [[Florence Shirley]] and her husband, headed for a European vacation. [[Cecil Arden]], a [[mezzo-soprano]] with the [[Metropolitan Opera]], and [[botanist]] [[Otto Warburg (botanist)|Otto Warburg]] sailed on the same trip.{{cite news | title = Norwegian fjords attract tourists | work = The New York Times | date = 21 June 1923 | page = 23 }} == Panama Pacific Line service, 1923–1925 == In April 1923, IMM announced that ''Kroonland'' and sister ship ''Finland'' would be returned to the Panama Pacific Line beginning in late September, sailing from New York to San Francisco via [[Havana]], the Panama Canal, and Los Angeles, with Los Angeles being the west coast hub of operations.{{cite news | title = Two large ships will come here | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 30 April 1923 | page = II–22 }} In June, ''Manchuria'' was also assigned to the route. See: {{cite news | title = I.M.M. Panama-Pacific Line | work = The Wall Street Journal | date = 22 June 1923 | page = 3 }} On 18 October, ''Kroonland'' departed on her first voyage on the route since 1915. ''Kroonland'' arrived in [[Port of Los Angeles|Los Angeles Harbor]] on 3 November amidst fanfare, becoming the largest liner to date to enter that harbor.{{cite news | title = Relinks New York with the Pacific | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 3 November 1923 | page = II–1 }}On ''Kroonland''{{'}}s previous visits, she had to anchor offshore and use [[lighter (barge)|lighters]] to transfer passengers and cargo. See: {{cite news | title = Notables welcome Kroonland | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 4 November 1923 | page = I–3 }} [[Image:SS Kroonland in Panama Canal, 1923.jpg|thumb|left|''Kroonland'' passes through the Pedro Miguel Locks of the [[Panama Canal]] on 23 October 1923. It was the liner's first voyage on the New York – San Francisco route after an absence of eight years.]] In contrast to her time on the North Atlantic, ''Kroonland'' encountered few weather or mechanical delays on the coast-to-coast route. In December 1923, however, the ship was delayed one day by unusually heavy seas and gales off [[Baja California]]. Another delay in October 1924 proved to be fatal, according to the ship's physician. An arrival two days late, caused by adverse currents north of Panama,{{cite news | title = Storms delay liners | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 17 October 1924 | page = A–20 }} cost a female passenger her life. Had the ship not been delayed, the physician believed, prompt hospital care could have saved her. On this same trip, ''Kroonland'' passed through a "hurricane zone" but was not adversely affected by the storm.{{cite news | title = Death victor in race with ship | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 20 October 1924 | page = 15 }}In all probability the "hurricane zone" referred to the [[1924 Cuba hurricane|Cuba hurricane]] (12–23 October) of the [[1924 Atlantic hurricane season|1924 season]] that formed in the [[Caribbean Sea]] off the [[Yucatan Peninsula]] and moved across Cuba, Florida, and into the Atlantic. In December 1924, the Panama Pacific Line announced that it would add {{SS|Mongolia|1903|2}} to the New York – California route in February to replace ''Kroonland''.{{cite news | title = Globe-circling vessel due at harbor today | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 15 December 1924 | page = 17 }} Even though press accounts reported as late as March 1925 that ''Kroonland'' had sailed her last on the route,{{cite news | title = Liner returns to Pacific | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 16 March 1925 | page = 10 }} she continued carrying passengers and cargo through at least June 1925 because of booming business. Although plans had been announced to convert ''Kroonland'' and ''Finland'' to freighters upon the delivery of two new ships ordered for the route in late 1924, there is no evidence that this was ever carried out.{{cite news | title = New liners for Panama Pacific | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 11 November 1924 | page = A22 }} === Notable passengers === ''Kroonland'' carried her share of notable passengers during her second stint for the Panama Pacific Line. On her first voyage, passengers included American [[Modernism|Modernist]] poet [[Wallace Stevens]] and his wife, Elsie. After transiting the Panama Canal, the liner headed north along the western coast of Mexico. The ship passed the [[Gulf of Tehuantepec|Gulf]] and [[Isthmus of Tehuantepec]] in early November, inspiring Stevens to later pen the poem "Sea Surface Full Of Clouds". First published in the July 1924 issue of literary magazine ''[[The Dial]]'',Cook, p. 80. it was later included in the 1931 edition of Stevens' ''[[Harmonium (poetry collection)|Harmonium]]''.Stevens, p. xi. Each of the five stanzas begins with the line "In that November off Tehuantepec" and is a different portrayal of the surface of the sea. The poem has been called one of Stevens' "most persuasive statements of the imagination's powers",Litz, pp. 150–51. and considered "the most perfect example of a 'pure poem'".Richardson, p. 22. Other notable passengers included [[Brooklyn Dodgers]] [[shortstop]] [[Ray E. French]], who sailed with his wife to their home in California on the same voyage as Stevens.{{cite news | title = Two liners carry tourists abroad | work = The New York Times | date = 18 October 1923 | page = 33 }} California artist [[William Barr (artist)|William Barr]], American author [[Frederick O'Brien]],{{cite news | title = Sea route takes tourists to coast | work = The New York Times | date = 6 December 1923 | page = 19 }} and actress [[Mary Carr]] all sailed on ''Kroonland'' in December 1923.{{cite news | title = Kroonland is held back by gales at sea | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 21 December 1923 | page = I–17 }} In February 1924, [[Daniel Willard]], president of the [[Baltimore and Ohio Railroad]], sailed from New York to Los Angeles. Acknowledging that the Panama Canal had "detract[ed] volumes of freight" from railroads, Willard said that there was no cause for alarm because the railroad business was booming.{{cite news | title = Liner carries notables | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 10 February 1924 | page = C–12 }} In January 1925, [[Gene Byrnes]], creator of the [[comic strip]] ''[[Reg'lar Fellers]]'', sailed from New York to Los Angeles with his wife.{{cite news | title = New motorship departs today | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 25 January 1925 | page = 14 }} On the same voyage, [[University of Southern California]] president [[Rufus B. von KleinSmid]] boarded ''Kroonland'' at Panama after attending the [[Pan-American Scientific Congress]] in Lima.{{cite news | title = Dr. von KleinSmid back | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 25 January 1925 | page = 20 }} In mid-June the same year, short story author and screenwriter [[H. C. Witwer]] and his family returned to New York aboard the ship.{{cite news | title = Kroonland sails with limit load | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 16 June 1925 | page = 17 }} == American Line service, 1925–1926 == [[Image:1926 Miami Hurricane damage.jpg|thumb|450px|right|''Kroonland''{{'}}s New York – Miami service was not renewed following the [[1926 Miami Hurricane]] which struck the city in September and caused widespread damage.]] In October 1925, the American Line announced plans for the liner to sail on a weekly New York – Miami route. ''Kroonland'', supplanted {{SS|H. F. Alexander||2}}{{SS|H. F. Alexander||2}} was a later name for ''Great Northern'', the ship that transited the Panama Canal the same day as ''Kroonland'' back in February 1915. of the Admiral Line as the largest ship in Miami service, and sailed from [[Chelsea Piers|Pier 62]] in New York on Thursdays, arrived and departed Miami on Sundays, and returned to New York on Wednesdays. Though ''Kroonland''{{'}}s passenger capacity was potentially much larger, she was outfitted for 500 passengers in first class only.{{cite news | title = Kroonland will be put on New York – Miami route for weekly run this winter | work = The Wall Street Journal | date = 23 October 1925 | page = 3 }} She sailed on her first voyage with 400 passengers, including American professional golfer [[Gene Sarazen]], on 10 December.{{cite news | title = Miami ship service inaugurated today | work = The New York Times | date = 10 December 1925 | page = 14 }} By the time the seasonal service to Miami ended in late March 1926,{{cite news | title = In the ship lanes | work = The Christian Science Monitor | date = 30 March 1926 | page = 6 }} ''Kroonland'' had carried 11,000 passengers on the route.{{cite news | title = Marine out of Miami business | work = The Wall Street Journal | date = 2 November 1926 | page = 10 }} Though plans were announced for the liner to resume the route the following winter, this did not happen. IMM offered no reasons, but conditions in Miami at the end of 1926 were very different from the previous year. The wild South Florida real estate boom had collapsed in mid 1926,{{cite news | last = McIver | first = Stuart | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/weather/hurricane/sfl-1926-hurricane,0,1292732.story | title = 1926 Miami: The blow that broke the boom | work = [[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]] | date = 19 September 1993 | accessdate = 21 June 2008 }} and the [[1926 Miami hurricane|Great Miami Hurricane]] struck on 18 September, killing more than 325 and leaving as many as 50,000 residents homeless, while causing some $100 million damage (just over $2 billion in 2005 dollars).{{ cite journal | last1= Pielke | first1= Roger A., Jr. | year = 2008 | title = Normalized Hurricane Damage in the United States: 1900–2005 | journal = Natural Hazards Review | volume = 9 | issue = 1 | pages = 29–42 | doi = 10.1061/(ASCE)1527-6988(2008)9:1(29) |display-authors=etal}} With no place to put the aging ship, IMM [[:wikt:laid up|laid up]] ''Kroonland'' in Hoboken. The ship was later sold to shipbreakers in Italy and departed the United States for the last time on 29 January 1927. After delivering a cargo of grain to her old homeport of Antwerp, she was taken to [[Genoa]] and scrapped. According to an Associated Press report, ''Kroonland'' had completed 234 voyages totaling {{convert|1635468|nmi|km}} during the course of her career without serious accident.{{cite news | agency = [[Associated Press]] | title = Razing of Kroonland at Genoa ordered | work = The Washington Post | date = 30 January 1927 | page = 16 }}The Associated Press article did not state whether the career totals included wartime service. == Notes == {{Reflist|group=Note}} == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == Bibliography == {{Refbegin}} * {{cite book | last = Bliss | first = Edward | title = Now The News: The Story of Broadcast Journalism | location = New York | publisher = [[Columbia University Press]] | year = 1991 | isbn = 978-0-231-04402-8 | oclc = 22731482 }} * {{cite book | last = Bonsor | first = N.
